results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 close-up of a moth on a leaf
00:00:38:00 large mushrooms in a grassy paddock
00:00:46:00 a woman slicing the mushrooms from the ground and collecting in a bucket
00:01:07:00 a largish spider runs up a canvas tent wall and the underside of a mushroom
00:01:22:00 peeling a large mushroom
00:01:52:00 a Coolabah brand wine cask and a poodle dog, mushrooms cooked on a camp stove
00:02:10:00 climbing over a stile in a fence
00:02:53:00 hikers climbing and helping each other over a rocky part of the trail
00:03:07:00 close-up of a spider in its web
00:04:07:00 descending a steep rock face
00:05:49:00 a iridescent blue and green beetle, tree lichen and a brown spider in its web
00:06:09:00 perfect light brown mushroom soon followed by another species of mushroom
00:06:54:00 several spiders on their webs
00:07:42:00 a variety of leather mushrooms
00:08:30:00 likely Ambicodamus crinitus spider
00:09:13:00 sign ‘Werribee Gorge’
00:09:30:00 hikers group sitting on the edge of a rocky cliff looking at the view, including a woman with binoculars
00:11:18:00 koala in close-up and and then climbing a tree
00:11:40:00 soaring Australian wedge-tailed eagle
00:12:07:00 group of (likely) bombadier beetles in green leaves
00:12:52:00 crossing the creek rock by rock
00:13:05:00 a small brown frog (likely litoria paraewingi)
00:13:12:00 hikers take a break - cameras, snacks and beer
00:15:02:00 overlooking tents at the camping site
00:15:17:00 wading the creek and a hiker rests with his dog on a hillside
00:15:55:00 leaf impressions on the rocks
00:16:36:00 1970s style cars - station wagons and camping van
00:16:55:00 two men using a manual post hole digger followed by scenes of fence making
00:17:29:00 planting new trees

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:35:00 walkers in the scrub
00:03:22:00 a koala peers at the camera
00:03:36:00 remains of a wooden sluice in a creek that may have been an old gold mining site
00:03:50:00 hearing instructions or a talk at a campsite with a fire
00:04:45:00 setting off on a walk through farm lands and gates
00:05:05:00 sheep run across a paddock and a swirling, foaming river spilling across rocks with spectacular waterfalls
00:06:52:00 collecting driftwood by the dramatic river
00:07:18:00 scenes showing the treacherous route for walking the banks of the swollen, fast flowing river
00:09:54:00 jumping from rock to rock over a creek
00:10:18:00 using logs to cross a creek
00:10:27:00 hikers walk up a long grassy hill with some sheep running by, toward a gravel quarry or storage area
00:11:03:00 looking for rock specimens or stones in the gravel
00:11:13:00 some hikers stop for a chat before scrambling over a rocky part of the hills
00:12:15:00 flowers, mushrooms and toadstools
00:13:08:00 a long lizard close-up followed by a centipede
00:14:40:00 a trickling creek before scenes of rushing waters in a small creek
00:15:50:00 country roads
00:16:29:00 filming a photographer taking pictures of wildflowers followed by close-ups of flowers
00:18:16:00 several wild orchids
00:19:15:00 a campfire at night
00:19:44:00 stone monument with a plaque that reads ‘Erected 1951. In memory of the pioneers of Steiglitz and the discovery of gold 1851 - 1853’
00:19:50:00 the the lovely brick Steiglitz Court House among gumtrees, a plain but lovely old house across the road and a farm cottage next to an old chimney that could be all that remains of an earlier house
00:20:33:00 a flock of ducks or geese
00:20:45:00 an old brick fireplace surrounded by the trees and bushes that have overtaken it, followed by several ageing weatherboard buildings
00:21:23:00 sign ‘Walking track to Flinders Peak’ (in the You Yangs, Victoria) followed by views from a higher vantage point in the You Yangs
00:22:19:00 views of jutting rocks and outcrops and some of the farmland beyond the You Yangs
00:23:48:00 plaque for ‘Matthew Flinders RN who stood on this rock to survey the bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace films the city of Shanghai in China, and its people. Crowded streets, heavy traffic (with many bicycles), houses, shops and other buildings, gardens, the city’s canals and port are features. There are scenes of people at work, and children in organised cultural activities, and a sequence of high-vantage-point views of the city dissolve into one another. The Jade Buddha Temple with its many statues is also featured.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Shanghai’, ‘Filmed by W.H.C’
00:01:26:99 carpet weaving
00:02:34:00 jade ‘Buddha Temple’ and its Buddha statues
00:04:57:00 various views of the city from high vantage points, in a sequence of dissolves.
00:05:56:00 young children at school or kindergarten
00:11:50:00 port and ships
00:13:41:00 shadow puppet play
00:14:04:00 young children in various music, calligraphy, arts and electronics activities in a sequence of dissolves. Some children wear the red scarf of the ‘Young Pioneers of China’ youth organisation.
00:15:45:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows Wallace and companions on a trip around the ‘High Country’ in northern Victoria starting with the township of Matlock - the fortunes and population of which went up and down through the gold rush in the 1800s to logging in the 1950s - and a summer visit to the alpine district of Mount Buller.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:40:00 road sign for ‘Matlock’ followed by views of the small town, old timber houses, rusty corregated iron sheds and roofs, old vehicles
00:01:08:00 stacks of logged timber
00:02:01:00 signpost to ‘Warburton, Moe, Walhalla’ and other destinations followed by the road into ‘Woods Point’
00:02:30:00 driving along country roads and by a creek, a large lake and a waterfall
00:04:30:00 hikers on a hilly trail that features electricity pylons and overhead wires that seem to be of interest
00:04:45:00 looking out over grassy hills sprinkled with wildflowers and electricity infrastructure
00:05:20:00 close-up of yellow wildflowers and yellow 1970s style headscarf tied at the nape of the neck
00:05:31:00 hikers taking photos of flowers or grasses
00:05:45:00 travellers and children descending a rocky hill walk
00:06:17:00 the ‘fire lookout tower’ on the summit of Mt Buller, constructed in the 1960s, followed by views from the summit
00:08:12:00 a glimpse of what appears to be the ‘Enzian Hotel On Chamois’ built by local Austrians looking for a European alpine experience
00:08:20:00 views out over the mountain peaks
00:09:17:00 two people sitting in the bush with a ‘billy’ can followed by more wildflowers and views out over rocky and grassy terrain
00:12:41:00 hikers walking around large boulders on the hills
00:13:01:00 picnic on a large cut off tree trunk
00:13:05:00 a yellow ‘Walkabouters Club’ t-shirt being worn by one of the hikers
00:13:27:00 wading in the creek
00:14:06:00 an ‘A-frame’ house or chalet in the bush
00:14:40:00 a motorbike parked on a foot bridge over a creek and people in the water
00:16:05:00 a lovely old building on the creek, including rusty corregated iron

This film shows Wallace and companions on a trip around the ‘High Country’ in northern Victoria starting with the township of Matlock - the fortunes and population of which went up and down through the gold rush in the 1800s to logging in the 1950s - and a summer visit to the alpine district of Mount Buller.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace and companions tour ‘Ayers Rock’ (Uluru) as it was then named, and ‘The Olgas’ (Kata Tjuta), and he provides some context for both sites, Indigenous names and the connection to local Indigenous Australians.

In acknowledging the importance of Uluru to Indigenous Australians Wallace provides a respectful and admiring narrative. However, information and context of the 1960s is unlikely to be as accurate or as sensitive as a narrative prepared with or by current traditional owners. (In 1985 the Australian Government returned Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park to the traditional owners of the area – the Anangu).

Originally made on Super 8mm film, with a sound track and voiceover narrative.

00:00:02:00 title card ‘Land of the Pitjandjara’ (Pitjantjatjara)
00:00:42:00 we see Mount Conner, as stated by the voiceover
00:01:10:00 a large pelican in the sandy landscape and voiceover explaining ‘Curtin Springs is one of the great cattle stations of the (red) centre’, and travellers stand around a well packed ‘Land Rover’ off-road motor car
00:01:30:00 filming from the car along a muddy track
00:01:40:00 travellers from buses gather wood for campfires as the narrator explains their destination is ‘Ayers Rock (Uluru)’, followed by stacking dead mulga branches ‘atop the vehicles’
00:02:00:00 driving under stone entry gate and ironwork sign ‘Ayers Rock and Mount Olga’
00:02:19:00 approaching Uluru
00:02:38:00 a ‘Tjintir-tjintirpa’ (willy wagtail) pecking at dry scrub grass while Wallace’s narration gives a brief description of the connection of local Indigenous Australians, the Indigenous name ‘Uluru’ and context in which it sits, the ‘dreamtime’ legends
00:03:28:00 views of the northern, or as Wallace points out, ‘the sunny side of the Rock’
00:04:00:00 views around the base of Uluru and Wallace continues his narrative
00:04:20:00 a long shallow cave
00:04:30:00 ‘The Olgas’ (Kata Tjuta) on the horizon a short distance away from Uluru
00:04:43:00 close-up of ‘the Kangaroo Tail’, a long detached piece of rock stretching across Uluru
00:05:08:00 a ‘wet weather cave’ that Wallace describes as ‘especially significant’ that contains Indigenous rock art. Wallace explains that this art depicts ‘totemic symbols’, which are ‘attributed to the dreamtime heroes’ and only a ‘chosen few of the tribe’ can work on the artworks for conservation. The soundtrack changes to include some traditional singing.
00:05:53:00 close-ups of beautiful rock formations at the base of Uluru
00:06:28:00 the travellers climbing on ‘the western end’ according to Wallace’s narrative
00:07:00:00 a dingo approaches the camera
00:07:24:00 filming from a vehicle approaching Kata Tjuta; the road is flooded or as Wallace narrates, more like ‘a canal’ than a road, needing a ‘good deal of reconnaissance’
00:08:13:00 dramatic footage of the vehicles driving through the muddy water covering the road
00:08:56:00 sunrise filmed as it lights up the eastern side of Kata Tjuta, which Wallace describes in very artistic terms
00:09:15:00 the travellers have breakfast at their campsite
00:09:30:00 views of the ‘Walpa Gorge Walk’ and difficult spots for walking or climbing
00:10:08:00 the travellers drinking directly from Walpa Creek by lying down
00:10:51:00 the travellers sit for lunch between the giant ‘tors’ (isolated weathered rocks) which make up Kata Tjuta, on the other side of the Walpa Gorge
00:11:12:10 various views around as the travellers walk ‘into the heart of the Olgas’
00:12:40:00 ‘gazing out across the expansive desert’ to the ‘Petermann Ranges’
00:13:06:00 birds, insects and a goanna as well as more views of the monolith rocks along the way back to the campsite
00:14:19:00 small tents at the campsite and views back to Kata Tjuta
00:14:56:00 title card ‘The End’ features a silhouette of an Indigenous Australian man and spear sitting on a rock looking out over the land

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part one of two and is titled ‘Festival City’. Wallace and companions travel by car to Adelaide in South Australia, filming the trip as they go.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Festival City’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:02:18:00 ‘Waterfalls Gully’ enroute to Adelaide
00:03:15:00 women posing with their cameras for the filmmaker’s camera.
00:03:39:00 women standing in front of a rock walk before climbing.
00:04:49:00 Adelaide Arts Centre.
00:05:16:00 paddle boats and fountain on the Torrens River in Adelaide.
00:06:31:00 churches in Adelaide.
00:07:09:00 camping alongside a pop-up van.
00:08:06:00 looking at an outdoor art exhibition.
00:09:42:00 sheep in a paddock.
00:10:03:00 historic ‘Peerless Roller Mills’ building in ‘Birdwood’, South Australia.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Orchid Isle’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:23:00 boats and yachts in small harbour.
00:01:36:00 Fijian musicians wearing elaborate floral costumes performing in an outdoor setting.
00:02:10:00 Fijian style thatched houses.
00:03:01:00 turtle swimming.
00:04:55:00 tourists participating in cultural performance.
00:05:35:00 palm weaving being shown to tourists.
00:06:51:00 passengers onboard a ferry listening to local musicians.
00:09:43:00 large ship at port in Suva.
00:10:18:00 local traffic in Suva.
00:10:30:00 marching military band in Suva.

description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.
